results.title: Thailand - do good receive good, do evil receive evil
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, University of Queensland Press, Film Australia and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
A look at the historical and cultural background of Thailand - this film attempts to address racist preconceptions about Thai people and their beliefs and rituals. Concentrates on two elements that affect all Thais: Buddhism and the role of the monarchy. It points out how the Monks appear to be losing their leadership roles as Thai society becomes more urbanised and how the Government is attempting to inform the Monks about social change so they don’t lose their place in society. Includes one or two scenes of violence (burning bodies, slaughter etc.) from newsreels. Presented by John Temple.
results.title_for_label: Thailand - do good receive good, do evil receive evil
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, University of Queensland Press, Film Australia and ABC

results.title: Japan: the bamboo bends and does not break
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, Film Australia and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
Provides insight into the historical and cultural background of Japan, drawing attention to the sense of duty and obligation held by the Japanese in ways that are different from people in the West. Photography by Dean Semler. Unit Manager: Damien Parer.

results.title: Indonesia
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, University of Queensland Press, Film Australia and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
What makes this diverse chain of islands into a nation? Indonesia’s national motto “Unity in diversity” is the film’s starting point in its concentration on Sumatra, Java and Bali - the most populated areas. One of the most interesting sequences is an examination of the Indonesian concept of power - that there is a finite amount of it in the world. Another highlight is the Indonesian Army and its role as an essential ingredient in society - not, as so often in the West, as something appended to, or imposed on, society.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, University of Queensland Press, Film Australia and ABC

results.title: ARTV
results.brief_description:
The Australian Centre for the Moving Image and SBS Independent will commission 16 artists to produce works for ARTV, an exhibition program which will be broadcast on SBS and shown on screens throughout ACMI concurrently, commencing on 8 June 2004.

ARTV is part of 2004, a survey exhibition of contemporary Australian visual culture presented by the Australian Centre for the Moving Image and the National Gallery of Victoria.

results.title: School of Paris (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Artists at Work”.
Five contemporary artists at work in Paris: Dewasne, working in pure colours, primaries dominating, the work somewhere between music and architecture; Di Teana, at work in steel, winner of the Prix de Saint Goba, 1962; Fruhtrunk - bands orange to black, the colours play as a Bach fugue; Weisbuch - continues the Daumier tradition - and winner of the Prix de la Critique for the best show in Paris, 1961; and Hartung - one of the most important influences on abstract, and prize winner at the Venice Biennale, 1960.

results.title: Between genius and the abyss
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The few years between the opening of the 20th Century and the outbreak of the First World War saw a radical transformation in artistic styles and design. Never before, had there been such an extension of visual language or multiplicity of styles and never had so much innovation taken place in such a short space of time. This episode higlights movements such as the Secession Movement, Expressionism, Fauvism, Cubism and Futurism and the artists from each period.
